conbody.p: The CLI stores credentials specified in with aws configure in a local file named credentials in a folder named .aws in your home directory. Home directory location varies but can be reffered to used the environment variables %userProfile% in Windows and $HOME or ~ (tilde) in Unix-like systems.
For example, the following commands list the contents of the .aws folder:
In order to separate credentials from less sensitive options, region, and output formats are stores in a separate file named config in the same folder.
The default file location for the config file can be overriddern by setting the AWS_CONFIG_FILE environment variable to another local pathe. See Environment Variables for details.

The AWS CLI will also read credntials from the config file. If you wabnt to keep all your profiles settings in a single file, you can. If there are ever credentials in both locations for a profile (say you used aws configure to update the profile's keys), the keys in the credentials file will take precedence.
If you use one of the SDKs in addition to the AWS CLI, you may notice additional warnings if credentials are not stored in their own file.
The files generated by the CLI for the profioe configured in the previous section look like this:
aws_session_token — AWS session token. A session token is only required if you are using temporary security credentials.
output — output format (json, text, or table).
